title: Project Proposal
text:
Proposal – Dallas Animals

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(readr)


readr::read_csv("week18_dallas_animals.csv")%>%
  head(n = 5)

# A tibble: 5 × 13
  animal_id animal_type animal_breed   month  year census_tract council_district
  <chr>     <chr>       <chr>          <chr> <dbl> <chr>        <chr>           
1 A0979593  DOG         RHOD RIDGEBACK FEB    2017 1502         2               
2 A0743013  DOG         YORKSHIRE TERR NOV    2016 13609        11              
3 A1004433  BIRD        CHICKEN        AUG    2017 10803        3               
4 A0969724  DOG         GERM SHEPHERD  DEC    2016 7102         2               
5 A0981479  DOG         GERM SHEPHERD  FEB    2017 6001         4               
# ℹ 6 more variables: intake_type <chr>, intake_date <chr>, outcome_type <chr>,
#   outcome_date <chr>, chip_status <chr>, animal_origin <chr>

dog <- read_csv("week18_dallas_animals.csv")


#Code for dataframe dimensions
print(dim(dog))

[1] 34819    13


Data Overview
This data set uses information from a variety of different animal shelters across the City of Dallas, upon their intake to the shelter. Each observation/row is an individual animal entered by staff into the shelter system. There are 34819 observations. The data is across all animal types including dogs, cats and other wildlife.
We chose this data set because we are dog lovers and one of our group members is from Dallas and volunteered at a local shelter. It also seemed to have well collected data with a lot of diversity within key variables like dog breed and intake form.
Variables:
1) Animal_id (ID number for each animals)
2) Animal_type (dog, cat, wildlife)
3) Animal_Breed
4) Month (intake month)
5) Month (intake Year)
6) Census_tract (Geographical Location)
7) Council_district (Geographical Boundries)
8) Intake_type
9) Outcome_type
10) Outcome_date(When animals leave the shelter)
11) Chip_status (is the animal chipped?)
12) animal_origin (How they got the animal)
Discussion Questions

Which city council districts have the highest rate of adoption? (council_district and outcome_type).

Filter outcome_type for observations only including adoptions using dplyr.
Quantify how many observations of adoptions there are in each district.
Graph using bar graph with ggplot2.

What types of animal intake tend to stay longer in shelters?

Mutate new variable for duration of stay with dplyr
Graph using bar graph with error bars for average stay (y axis) and type of intake (x axis) with ggplot2

title: Project Write-up
text:
Your write-up should consist of three parts:


Brief introduction to the dataset. You may repeat some of the information about the dataset provided in the introduction to the dataset on the TidyTuesday repository, for instance. Imagine that your project is a standalone document and the grader has no prior knowledge of the dataset.


The title should relate to the question you’re answering.


Introduction to the question and what parts of the dataset are necessary to answer the question. Also discuss why you’re interested in this question.



Describe what types of plots you are going to make to address your question. For each plot, provide a clear explanation as to why this plot (e.g. boxplot, barplot, histogram, etc.) is best for providing the information you are asking about. The two plots should be of different types, and at least one of the two plots needs to use either color mapping or facets.



In this section, provide the code that generates your plots. Use scale functions to provide nice axis labels and guides. You are welcome to use theme functions to customize the appearance of your plot, but you are not required to do so. All plots must be made with ggplot2. Do not use base R or lattice plotting functions.



In the Discussion section, interpret the results of your analysis. Identify any trends revealed (or not revealed) by the plots. Speculate about why the data looks the way it does.




Same structure outlined for Question 1, but for your new question. And the title should relate to the question you’re answering.
We encourage you to be concise. A paragraph should typically not be longer than 5 sentences.
You are not required to perform any statistical tests in this project, but you may do so if you find it helpful to answer your question.

title: Project Presentation
text:
Outline

Your presentation should generally follow the same structure as your write-up.
Each team will have 5 minutes for their presentation, and each team member must speak (roughly equally) during this time.
Your presentation will be created using Quarto, which allows you to write slides using the same coding structure you’re used to with Rmarkdown.
This is a sample Quarto slide template you can edit to your desire to create your presentation.

title: Project Presentation: Dallas Dogs
text:
Rubric

Roughly I recommend 1 slide for introduction, 2 slides for Question 1, ans 2 slides for Question 2.

You can imagine spending roughly one minute on each slide.
You should feel free to have more (or fewer) slides.

Your evaluation will be based on your content, professionalism (including sticking to time), and your performance during the Q&A (question and answer). We don’t care how many slides you use to do this.

title: About
text: This project is developed by Adrien as a template for the first mini-project of Math/Stat 241 at Reed College.

title: Dallas Dog - write-up
text:
Write-up Your write-up should consist of three parts:
Introduction (1-2 paragraphs): Brief introduction to the dataset. You may repeat some of the information about the dataset provided in the introduction to the dataset on the TidyTuesday repository (or from the dataset provider if you found the dataset elsewhere). Imagine that your project is a standalone document and the grader has no prior knowledge of the dataset.
Question 1: The title should relate to the question you’re answering.
Introduction (1-2 paragraphs): Introduction to the question and what parts of the dataset are necessary to answer the question. Also discuss why you’re interested in this question.
Approach (1-2 paragraphs): Describe what types of plots you are going to make to address your question. For each plot, provide a clear explanation as to why this plot (e.g. boxplot, barplot, histogram, etc.) is best for providing the information you are asking about. The two plots should be of different types, and at least one of the two plots needs to use either color mapping or facets.
Analysis (2-3 code blocks, 2 figures, text/code comments as needed): In this section, provide the code that generates your plots. Use scale functions to provide nice axis labels and guides. You are welcome to use theme functions to customize the appearance of your plot, but you are not required to do so. All plots must be made with ggplot2. Do not use base R or lattice plotting functions.
Discussion (1-3 paragraphs): In the Discussion section, interpret the results of your analysis. Identify any trends revealed (or not revealed) by the plots. Speculate about why the data looks the way it does.
Question 2: Same structure outlined for Question 1, but for your new question. And the title should relate to the question you’re answering.
We encourage you to be concise. A paragraph should typically not be longer than 5 sentences.
You are not required to perform any statistical tests in this project, but you may do so if you find it helpful to answer your question.
Introduction:
Our dataset we chose
This data set uses information from a variety of different animal shelters across the City of Dallas, upon their intake to the shelter. Each observation/row is an individual animal entered by staff into the shelter system. There are 34819 observations. The data is across all animal types including dogs, cats and other wildlife.
We chose this data set because we are dog lovers and one of our group members is from Dallas and volunteered at a local shelter. It also seemed to have well collected data with a lot of diversity within key variables like dog breed and intake form.

title: The Real House Pets of Dallas
section: Example of a Dog in Dallas:
text: Example of a Dog in Dallas:

title: The Real House Pets of Dallas
The Real House Pets of Dallas
text:
Our Opening Spiel:
Using publicly available data supplied by the venerable animal shelters of the City of Dallas, we set out to cultivate a clearer understanding of who adopts, and who gets adopted.
This was achieved by examining two key questions, those being:

Which city council districts have the highest rate of adoption?
What types of animal intake tend to stay longer in shelters?

title: The Real House Pets of Dallas
text:
Q1, Dallas Adopters Club:
To tackle the first of these two questions, the variables council_district and outcome_type were isolated to allow for each district to be measured against the number of animals taken into shelters whose case was resolved in adoption.
With a clearer picture of where adoption rates are highest, resources supporting shelter operations may be more effectively allocated, improving outcomes for prospective adopters and the adoptees they might hope to take in.

title: The Real House Pets of Dallas
text:
Dallas Adopters Club (Cont’):
Here is what we found:

title: The Real House Pets of Dallas
text:
Dallas Adopters Club (Cont’) (Cont’):
(I took a few swipes at getting some nice language here, but I think the conclusions section of the presentation probably deserves some collective input. As a placeholder, I have paraphrased the conclusion from the write-up)
Adoption rates proved to be highly variable across council districts, with the top spots going to districts 1, 4, 6, and 8. Districts with the lowest rates of adoption include 10-14. From this, we may conclude that geography plays a major role in pet adoption in the City of Dallas.

title: The Real House Pets of Dallas
text:
Q2, Those that Linger:
Turning to our second query, we weighed the manner of intake which animals underwent against the duration of their stay in a shelter. This was done by constructing a measurement from the intake date to the outtake date (dog_duration), and charting it against intake_type.
We then generated three visualizations from which to glean trends.

title: The Real House Pets of Dallas
The Real House Pets of Dallas
The Real House Pets of Dallas
The Real House Pets of Dallas
text:
Those that Linger (Cont’) (Cont’) (Cont’) (Cont’):
(Also leaving this with a placeholder for the mo’ – I imagine we really only need three or four lines describing our takeaways.)
Observing the data, we found that Owner Surrender and Stray were the two most common forms of intake. In terms of duration, intake via Foster, Wildlife, Owner Surrender, and Stray correlated with the briefest tenures in shelter care, with Found and Lost Report correlating with lengthier stays.

title: The Real House Pets of Dallas
text:
Thank you for Listening
Now go out and adopt an animal, volunteer at a shelter, or just [funny third thing]
